introduction.p: The last section demonstrated ways in which we may relate a matrix, and the effect that multiplication has on vectors, to a simpler form. For instance, if there is a basis of \real^n consisting of eigenvectors of A, we saw that A is similar to a diagonal matrix D. As a result, the effect of multiplying vectors by A, when expressed using the basis of eigenvectors, is the same as multiplying by D.

In this section, we will put these ideas to use as we explore discrete dynamical systems, first encountered in . Recall that we used a state vector \xvec to characterize the state of some system at a particular time, such as the distribution of delivery trucks between two locations. A matrix A described the transition of the state vector with A\xvec characterizing the state of the system at a later time. Since we would like to understand how the state vector evolves over time, we are interested in studying the sequence of vectors A^k\xvec.
Our goal in this section is to describe the types of behaviors that dynamical systems exhibit and to develop a means of detecting these behaviors.

Suppose that we have a diagonalizable matrix A=PDP^{-1} where
P = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp -1 \\ 1 \amp 2 \\ \end{array}\right],\qquad D = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -3 \\ \end{array}\right] .

statement.p: Find the eigenvalues of A and find a basis for the associated eigenspaces.

solution.p: Since A has been diagonalized as A=PDP^{-1}, the eigenvalues of A are the diagonal entries of D and the eigenvectors are the columns of P. Therefore, we know the eigenvalues are \lambda_1=2 with associated eigenvector \vvec_1=\twovec11 and \lambda_2=-3 with associated eigenvector \vvec_2=\twovec{-1}{2}.

statement.p: Form a basis of \real^2 consisting of eigenvectors of A and write the vector \xvec = \twovec{1}{4} as a linear combination of basis vectors.

solution.p: The columns of P, \vvec_1 and \vvec_2, form a basis for \real^2. We find that \xvec=\twovec14 = 2\vvec_1+\vvec_2.

statement.p: Write A\xvec as a linear combination of basis vectors.
For some power k, write A^k\xvec as a linear combination of basis vectors.

subsection.title: A first example
subsection.p: We will begin with a dynamical system that illustrates how the ideas we've been developing can help us understand the populations of two interacting species. There are several possible ways in which two species may interact. For example, wolves on Isle Royale in northern Michigan prey on moose so this interaction is often called a predator-prey relationship. Other interactions between species, such as bees and flowering plants, are mutually beneficial for both species.

statement.p: Suppose we have two species R and S that interact with each another and that we record the change in their populations from year to year. When we begin our study, the populations, measured in thousands, are R_0 and S_0; after k years, the populations are R_k and S_k.

We will record the populations in a vector \xvec_k = \twovec{R_k}{S_k} and note that \xvec_{k+1} = A\xvec_k where A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0.9 \amp 0.8 \\ 0.2 \amp 0.9 \\ \end{array}\right] .
Verify that
\vvec_1=\twovec{2}{1},\qquad \vvec_2=\twovec{-2}{1}
are eigenvectors of A and find their respective eigenvalues.
Suppose that initially \xvec_0 = \twovec{2}{3}. Write \xvec_0 as a linear combination of the eigenvectors \vvec_1 and \vvec_2.
Write the vectors \xvec_1, \xvec_2, and \xvec_3 as linear combinations of the eigenvectors \vvec_1 and \vvec_2.
What happens to \xvec_k after a very long time?
When k becomes very large, what happens to the ratio of the populations R_k/S_k?
After a very long time, by approximately what factor does the population of R grow every year? By approximately what factor does the population of S grow every year?
If we begin instead with \xvec_0 = \twovec{4}{4}, what eventually happens to the ratio R_k/S_k as k becomes very large?

li.p: We find that A\vvec_1=\twovec{2.6}{1.3} = 1.3\vvec_1 and A\vvec_2=\twovec{-1}{0.5}=0.5\vvec_2. This shows that \vvec_1 and \vvec_2 are eigenvectors with associated eigenvalues \lambda_1=1.3 and \lambda_2=0.5.
Solving for the weights of the linear combination of \vvec_1 and \vvec_2 that produces \xvec_0, we find that \xvec_0=2\vvec_1+\vvec_2.

Each time we multiply by A, the eigenvectors are multiplied by their associated eigenvalues. This gives
\begin{aligned} \xvec_1 = A\xvec_0 \amp = 2(1.3)\vvec_1 + 0.5\vvec_2 \\ \xvec_2 = A\xvec_1 \amp = 2(1.3)^2\vvec_1 + 0.5^2\vvec_2 \\ \xvec_3 = A\xvec_2 \amp = 2(1.3)^3\vvec_1 + 0.5^3\vvec_2\text{.} \\ \end{aligned}
After a long time 0.5^k\approx 0 so we have \xvec_k \approx 2(1.3)^k\vvec_1.

More generally, we have \xvec_k=2(1.3)^k\vvec_1 + 0.5^k\vvec_2. As k grows large, 0.5^k becomes insignificantly small so that \xvec_k\approx 2(1.3)^k\vvec_1. This means that R_k\approx 4(1.3)^k and S_k\approx2(1.3)^k so that the ratio R_k/S_k \approx 2.
We see that \xvec_{k+1}\approx 1.3\xvec_k so that the populations both grow by a factor of approximately 1.3, which is a 30% growth rate.

Now we have \xvec_0 = 3\vvec_1 + \vvec_2. In the same way, when k is very large, we have \xvec_k\approx 3(1.3)^k\vvec_1 so that R_k\approx6(1.3)^k and S_k\approx3(1.3)^k. This gives the same ratio: R_k/S_k\approx 2.

subsection.p: This activity demonstrates the type of systems we will be considering. In particular, we will have vectors \xvec_k that describe the state of the system at time k and a matrix A that describes how the state evolves from one time to the next: \xvec_{k+1} = A\xvec_k. The eigenvalues and eigenvectors of A provide the key that helps us understand how the vectors \xvec_k evolve and that enables us to make long-range predictions.

Let's look at the specific example in the previous activity more carefully. We see that
\xvec_{k+1} = A\xvec_k = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0.9 \amp 0.8 \\ 0.2 \amp 0.9 \\ \end{array}\right] \xvec_k
and that the matrix A has eigenvectors \vvec_1 = \twovec{2}{1} and \vvec_2=\twovec{-2}{1} with associated eigenvalues \lambda_1=1.3 and \lambda_2=0.5.

Let's shift our perspective slightly. The eigenvectors \vvec_1 and \vvec_2 form a basis \bcal of \real^2, which says that A is diagonalizable; that is, A = PDP^{-1} where
P = \left[\begin{array}{rr} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 2 \amp -2 \\ 1 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right], \qquad D = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1.3 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0.5 \\ \end{array}\right].

The coordinate system defined by the basis \bcal can be used to express the state vectors. For instance, we can write the initial state vector \xvec_0=\twovec{2}{3}= 2\vvec_1+\vvec_2, which means that \coords{\xvec_0}{\bcal} = \twovec{2}{1}. Moreover, \xvec_1=A\xvec_0 = (1.3)\cdot2\vvec_1 + (0.5)\cdot1\vvec_2 so that
\coords{\xvec_1}{\bcal} = \twovec{1.3\cdot 2}{0.5\cdot 1} = D\twovec21 = D\coords{\xvec_0}{\bcal}.
In the same way,
\begin{aligned} \coords{\xvec_1}{\bcal} \amp {}={} D\coords{\xvec_0}{\bcal} = \ctwovec{1.3\cdot 2}{0.5\cdot 1} \\ \coords{\xvec_2}{\bcal} \amp {}={} D\coords{\xvec_1}{\bcal} = \ctwovec{1.3^2\cdot 2}{0.5^2\cdot1} \\ \coords{\xvec_3}{\bcal} \amp {}={} D\coords{\xvec_2}{\bcal} = \ctwovec{1.3^3\cdot2}{0.5^3\cdot1} \\ \coords{\xvec_k}{\bcal} \amp {}={} \ctwovec{1.3^k\cdot2}{0.5^k\cdot1}\text{.} \\ \end{aligned}

More generally, we have
\coords{A\xvec}{\bcal} = D\coords{\xvec}{\bcal},
which is a restatement of the fact that A is similar to D.

sidebyside.p: Thinking about this geometrically, we begin with the vector \coords{\xvec_0}{\bcal}=\ctwovec{2}{1}. Subsequent vectors \coords{\xvec_k}{\bcal} are obtained by scaling horizontally by a factor of 1.3 and scaling vertically by a factor 0.5. Notice how the points move along a curve away from the origin becoming ever closer to the horizontal axis. After a very long time, \coords{\xvec_k}{\bcal} \approx \ctwovec{1.3^k\cdot2}{0}.

To recover the behavior of the sequence \xvec_0, \xvec_1, \xvec_2, \ldots, we change coordinate systems using the basis defined by \vvec_1 and \vvec_2. Here, the points move along a curve away from the origin becoming ever closer to the line defined by \vvec_1.

subsection.p:
Eventually, the vectors become practically indistinguishable from a scalar multiple of \vvec_1 = \twovec{2}{1} since \xvec_k\approx 1.3^k\cdot2\vvec_1. This means that
\xvec_k = \twovec{R_k}{S_k} \approx 1.3^k\cdot 2\vvec_1 = \twovec{1.3^k\cdot4}{1.3^k\cdot2}.
This shows that
R_k/S_k \approx (1.3^k\cdot 4) / (1.3^k\cdot 2) = 2
so that we expect the population of species R to eventually be about twice that of species S.

In addition, \xvec_{k+1} \approx 1.3\xvec_k so that R_{k+1}\approx 1.3 R_k and S_{k+1}\approx 1.3 S_k, which tells us that both populations are multiplied by 1.3 every year meaning the annual growth rate for both populations is about 30%.

In the same way, we can consider other possible initial populations \xvec_0 as shown in . Regardless of \xvec_0, the population vectors, in the coordinates defined by \bcal, are scaled horizontally by a factor of 1.3 and vertically by a factor of 0.5. The sequence of points \coords{\xvec_k}{\bcal}, called trajectories, move along the curves, as shown on the left. In the standard coordinate system, we see that the trajectories converge to the eigenspace E_{1.3}.

figure.caption: The trajectories of the dynamical system formed by the matrix A in the coordinate system defined by \bcal, on the left, and in the standard coordinate system, on the right.

subsection.p: We conclude that, regardless of the initial populations, the ratio of the populations R_k/S_k will approach 2 to 1 and that the growth rate for both populations approaches 30%. This example demonstrates the power of using eigenvalues and eigenvectors to rewrite the problem in terms of a new coordinate system. By doing so, we are able to predict the long-term behavior of the populations independently of the initial populations.

Diagrams like those shown in are called phase portraits. On the left of is the phase portrait of the diagonal matrix D=\mattwo{1.3}00{0.5} while the right of that figure shows the phase portrait of A = \mattwo{0.9}{0.8}{0.2}{0.9}. The phase portrait of D is relatively easy to understand because it is determined only by the two eigenvalues. Once we have the phase portrait of D, however, the phase portrait of A has a similar appearance with the eigenvectors \vvec_j replacing the standard basis vectors \evec_j.

subsection.title: Classifying dynamical systems
subsection.p: In the previous example, we were able to make predictions about the behavior of trajectories \xvec_k=A^k\xvec_0 by considering the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the matrix A. The next activity looks at a collection of matrices that demonstrate the types of behavior a 2\times2 dynamical system can exhibit.

statement.p:
We will now look at several more examples of dynamical systems. If P = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp -1 \\ 1 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] , we note that the columns of P form a basis \bcal of \real^2. Given below are several matrices A written in the form A=PEP^{-1} for some matrix E. For each matrix, state the eigenvalues of A and sketch a phase portrait for the matrix E on the left and a phase portrait for A on the right. Describe the behavior of A^k\xvec_0 as k becomes very large for a typical initial vector \xvec_0.
A=PEP^{-1} where
E = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1.3 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1.5 \\ \end{array}\right] .
A=PEP^{-1} where
E = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp -1 \\ 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] .
A=PEP^{-1} where
E = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0.7 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1.5 \\ \end{array}\right] .
A=PEP^{-1} where
E = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0.3 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0.7 \\ \end{array}\right] .
A=PEP^{-1} where
E = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp -0.9 \\ 0.9 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .
A=PEP^{-1} where
E = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0.6 \amp -0.2 \\ 0.2 \amp 0.6 \\ \end{array}\right] .

subsection.p:
This activity demonstrates six possible types of dynamical systems, which are determined by the eigenvalues of A.
Suppose that A has two real eigenvalues \lambda_1 and \lambda_2 and that both |\lambda_1|, |\lambda_2| \gt 1. In this case, any nonzero vector \xvec_0 forms a trajectory that moves away from the origin so we say that the origin is a repellor. This is illustrated in .
The origin is a repellor when |\lambda_1|, |\lambda_2| \gt 1.
Suppose that A has two real eigenvalues \lambda_1 and \lambda_2 and that |\lambda_1| \gt 1 \gt |\lambda_2| . In this case, most nonzero vectors \xvec_0 form trajectories that converge to the eigenspace E_{\lambda_1}. In this case, we say that the origin is a saddle as illustrated in .
The origin is a saddle when |\lambda_1|\gt 1 \gt |\lambda_2|.
Suppose that A has two real eigenvalues \lambda_1 and \lambda_2 and that both |\lambda_1|, |\lambda_2| \lt 1. In this case, any nonzero vector \xvec_0 forms a trajectory that moves into the origin so we say that the origin is an attractor. This is illustrated in .
The origin is an attractor when |\lambda_1|, |\lambda_2| \lt 1.
Suppose that A has a complex eigenvalue \lambda = a+bi where |\lambda| \gt 1. In this case, a nonzero vector \xvec_0 forms a trajectory that spirals away from the origin. We say that the origin is a spiral repellor, as illustrated in .
The origin is a spiral repellor when A has an eigenvalue \lambda=a+bi with a^2+b^2\gt 1.
Suppose that A has a complex eigenvalue \lambda = a+bi where |\lambda| = 1. In this case, a nonzero vector \xvec_0 forms a trajectory that moves on a closed curve around the origin. We say that the origin is a center , as illustrated in .
The origin is a center when A has an eigenvalue \lambda=a+bi with a^2+b^2 = 1.
Suppose that A has a complex eigenvalue \lambda = a+bi where |\lambda| \lt 1. In this case, a nonzero vector \xvec_0 forms a trajectory that spirals into the origin. We say that the origin is a spiral attractor, as illustrated in .
The origin is a spiral attractor when A has an eigenvalue \lambda=a+bi with a^2+b^2\lt 1.

This list includes many types of expected behavior, but there are other possibilities if, for instance, one of the eigenvalues is 0. The next section explores the situation when one of the eigenvalues is 1.

statement.p:
In this activity, we will consider several ways in which two species might interact with one another. Throughout, we will consider two species R and S whose populations in year k form a vector \xvec_k=\twovec{R_k}{S_k} and which evolve according to the rule
\xvec_{k+1}=A\xvec_k .
Suppose that A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0.7 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1.6 \\ \end{array}\right] .
Explain why the species do not interact with one another. Which of the six types of dynamical systems do we have? What happens to both species after a long time?
Suppose now that A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0.7 \amp 0.3 \\ 0 \amp 1.6 \\ \end{array}\right] .
Explain why S is a beneficial species for R. Which of the six types of dynamical systems do we have? What happens to both species after a long time?
If A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0.7 \amp 0.5 \\ -0.4 \amp 1.6 \\ \end{array}\right] , explain why this describes a predator-prey system. Which of the species is the predator and which is the prey? Which of the six types of dynamical systems do we have? What happens to both species after a long time?
Suppose that A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0.5 \amp 0.2 \\ -0.4 \amp 1.1 \\ \end{array}\right] . Compare this predator-prey system to the one in the previous part. Which of the six types of dynamical systems do we have? What happens to both species after a long time?

li.p: Because the eigenvalues are \lambda_1=0.7 and \lambda_2=1.6, this dynamical system is again a saddle. The associated eigenvectors are \vvec_1=\twovec10 and \vvec_2=\twovec13. After a long time, the population vector \xvec_k\approx c_1(1.6)^k\vvec_2 so both populations grow by a factor of 1.6 and with a ratio R_k/S_k=1/3.

We have eigenvectors \vvec_1=\twovec11 with associated eigenvalue \lambda_1=1.2 and \vvec_2=\twovec{5}{4} with \lambda_2=1.1. This dynamical system is a repellor so both species will grow arbitrarily large.

This example is similar to the previous one, but the coefficients are slightly different. We see that the growth rate of both species is smaller. For instance, in the previous problem, we had R_{k+1}=0.7R_k+\ldots while we now have R_{k+1}=0.5R_k+\ldots. This says that the reproduction rate of species R has decreased from 0.7 to 0.5. In the same way, that of species S has decreased from 1.6 to 1.1. Also, R_{k+1}=\ldots + 0.2S_k so the presence of species S is less beneficial to species R.
We now have the eigenvalues \lambda_1=0.9 and \lambda_2=0.7, which means that this dynamical system is an attractor and that both species will become extinct.

subsection.title: A 3\times3 system
subsection.p: Up to this point, we have focused on 2\times2 systems. In fact, the general case is quite similar. As an example, consider a 3\times3 system \xvec_{k+1}=A\xvec_k where the matrix A has eigenvalues \lambda_1 = 0.6, \lambda_2 = 0.8, and \lambda_3=1.1. Since the eigenvalues are real and distinct, there is a basis \bcal consisting of eigenvectors of A so we can look at the trajectories \coords{\xvec_k}{\bcal} in the coordinate system defined by \bcal. The phase portraits in show how some representative trajectories will evolve. We see that all the trajectories will converge into the eigenspace E_{1.1}.

figure.caption: In a 3\times3 system with \lambda_1 = 0.6, \lambda_2=0.8, and \lambda_3 = 1.1, the trajectories \coords{\xvec_k}{\bcal} move along the curves shown above.

subsection.p: In the same way, suppose we have a 3\times3 system with complex eigenvalues \lambda=0.8 \pm 0.5i and \lambda_3=1.1. Since the complex eigenvalues satisfy |\lambda| \lt 1, there is a two-dimensional subspace in which the trajectories spiral in toward the origin. The phase portraits in show some of the trajectories. Once again, we see that all the trajectories converge into the eigenspace E_{1.1}.

figure.caption: In a 3\times3 system with complex eigenvalues \lambda = a\pm bi with |\lambda| \lt 1 and \lambda_3=1.1, the trajectories \coords{\xvec_k}{\bcal} move along the curves shown above.

statement.p: The following type of analysis has been used to study the population of a bison herd. We will divide the population of female bison into three groups: juveniles who are less than one year old; yearlings between one and two years old; and adults who are older than two years.

sidebyside.p:
Each year,
80% of the juveniles survive to become yearlings.
90% of the yearlings survive to become adults.
80% of the adults survive.
40% of the adults give birth to a juvenile.

statement.p:
By J_k, Y_k, and A_k, we denote the number of juveniles, yearlings, and adults in year k. We have
J_{k+1} = 0.4 A_k .
Find similar expressions for Y_{k+1} and A_{k+1} in terms of J_k, Y_k, and A_k.
As is usual, we write the matrix \xvec_k=\threevec{J_k}{Y_k}{A_k}. Write the matrix A such that \xvec_{k+1} = A\xvec_k and find its eigenvalues.
We can write A = PEP^{-1} where the matrices E and P are approximately:
\begin{aligned} E \amp {}={} \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1.058 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -0.128 \amp -0.506 \\ 0 \amp 0.506 \amp -0.128 \\ \end{array}\right], \\ \\ P \amp {}={} \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0.756 \amp -0.378 \amp 1.486 \\ 2.644 \amp -0.322 \amp -1.264 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{aligned}
Make a prediction about the long-term behavior of \xvec_k. For instance, at what rate does it grow? For every 100 adults, how many juveniles, and yearlings are there?
Suppose that the birth rate decreases so that only 30% of adults give birth to a juvenile. How does this affect the long-term growth rate of the herd?
Suppose that the birth rate decreases further so that only 20% of adults give birth to a juvenile. How does this affect the long-term growth rate of the herd?
Find the smallest birth rate that supports a stable population.

li.p:
We have the relationships
\begin{alignedat}{4} J_{k+1} \amp {}={} \amp \amp \amp \amp \amp 0.4 A_k \\ Y_{k+1} \amp {}={} \amp 0.8 J_k \\ A_{k+1} \amp {}={} \amp \amp \amp 0.9Y_k \amp {}+{} \amp 0.8A_k\text{.} \\ \end{alignedat}
The matrix A=\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 \amp 0 \amp 0.4 \\ 0.8 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0.9 \amp 0.8 \\ \end{array}\right].

There is a real eigenvalue \lambda_1=1.058, which is larger than 1. The other eigenvalues are complex \lambda_{2,3} = -0.128\pm 0.506i and satisfy |\lambda_{2,3}| \lt 1. Therefore, the complex eigenvalues will pull vectors in toward the line defined by the eigenvector \vvec_1. After a long time, the population is \xvec_k\approx c_1(1.058)^k\vvec_1. All the populations grow annually by a factor of 1.058 or 5.8%, and there are approximately 38 juveniles and 29 yearlings for every 100 adults.
We now have eigenvalues \lambda_1=1.011 and \lambda_{2,3} = -0.106\pm 0.450i. This shows that the growth rate is lowered to 1.011 or 1.1% annually.
The first eigenvalue is \lambda_1=0.957 so the growth rate is about 96%. In other words, the population decreases every year.
To be stable, we need the first eigenvalue \lambda_1=1. If we experiment with different birth rates, we see that a birth rate of about 0.278 gives this eigenvalue.

subsection.title: Summary
subsection.p:
We have been exploring discrete dynamical systems in which an initial state vector \xvec_0 evolves over time according to the rule \xvec_{k+1}=A\xvec_k. The eigenvalues and eigenvectors of A help us understand the behavior of the state vectors. In the 2\times2 case, we saw that
|\lambda_1|, |\lambda_2| \lt 1 produces an attractor so that trajectories are pulled in toward the origin.
|\lambda_1| \gt 1 and |\lambda_2| \lt 1 produces a saddle in which most trajectories are pushed away from the origin and in the direction of E_{\lambda_1}.
|\lambda_1|, |\lambda_2| \gt 1 produces a repellor in which trajectories are pushed away from the origin.
The same kind of reasoning allows us to analyze n\times n systems as well.
